top_categories.workout_context: UCI Gravel Dustman's Gravel roads forces constant power changes. Surge over the rough stuff, settle on the smooth, repeat for 81 miles.
Race-pace efforts that mimic UCI Gravel Dustman's demands. Pacing, fueling, and tactical decisions under fatigue. Practice the race before November.
UCI Gravel Dustman's mixed gravel rewards steady threshold power. Surging and recovering costs more watts than just holding.
At mile 60 of 81, glycogen is gone. This workout teaches your body to produce watts on fumes.
88–92% FTP is where you'll spend the hardest sustained miles of UCI Gravel Dustman. Train it until it feels boring.
At UCI Gravel Dustman, surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding. Over-unders train exactly that.
When someone attacks on mixed gravel, you have 10 seconds to respond or you're off the back. This builds that response.
How long can you hold 105% FTP before you blow? At UCI Gravel Dustman, that number decides whether you bridge or get dropped.
2-minute all-out efforts on mixed gravel. Closing gaps, responding to attacks, sprinting for position. Train the burn.
Every hard session works better with a bigger aerobic base. At 81 miles, base fitness is the difference between racing and surviving.
Two threshold sessions per week without the recovery cost of VO2max work. For 81 miles, sustainable FTP gains matter more than peak power.
Long rides with hard efforts mixed in. Simulates what UCI Gravel Dustman's mixed gravel actually does to you.

race_overlay.nutrition: Target 60–80g carbs/hour for UCI Gravel Dustman’s 81 miles. Start fueling within the first 30 minutes — early fueling prevents late-race collapse. Bonking at mile 60 is a nutrition failure, not a fitness failure.
race_overlay.terrain: Mixed terrain at UCI Gravel Dustman requires surface adaptability. Include weekly rides on mixed gravel to build confidence. Expect: gravel roads.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on Gravel Specific, Race Simulation, and TT Threshold to prepare you for 81 miles of mixed gravel in Kanchanaburi, Thailand.
